description: On Friday, Edgecombe County reported 190 cases with nine deaths and 163 people recovered, while Nash County reported 198 total cases with four deaths and 125 people recovered. During a Friday morning Nash County team management meeting, Health Director Bill Hill reported that his agency was seeing an increased number of positives as testing has increased.
text:
While the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 continues to increase in the
Twin Counties, the concern over the number of confirmed cases among Hispanics
increases at an even greater rate.

On Friday, Edgecombe County reported 190 cases with nine deaths and 163 people
recovered, while Nash County reported 198 total cases with four deaths and 125
people recovered.

During a Friday morning Nash County team management meeting, Health Director
Bill Hill reported that his agency was seeing an increased number of positives
as testing has increased.

"We expected to see that with the increased testing," he said, "but we are
seeing more and more Hispanics (testing positive) and that is a concern."

Hill said that of six new cases heading into Friday, four people were
Hispanics. Over the Memorial Day weekend, six members of one Hispanic family,
including a 6-year-old, tested positive.

Hill said that in the six latest cases, there was a husband and wife in their
50s, as well as people in their 30s and 40s.

Edgecombe County provides no demographic information, claiming immunity under
HIPPA guidelines and citing a belief that by identifying a person testing
positive by gender or race, it could lead to their being identified.

Edgecombe County health department officials have declined to reply to at
least two e-mails regarding what County Manager Eric Evans told county
commissioners was an increasing number of cases among Hispanics.

The next week, when commissioners met in joint session with the Edgecombe
County Public Schools board, Evans backed off that statement and said only
that, "The demographics are changing daily."

While Edgecombe provides no updates, Nash has visited farm labor camps and met
with farmers in an effort to stem the growth of cases among Hispanics as the
migrant work force grows.

Even with that, Nash County Manager Zee Lamb said, "There does seems to be a
spike in the cases among Hispanics  disproportionately that demographic is
growing beyond their population."

Statewide, cases showed a slight decline on Friday in North Carolina, but the
number of positive case reports has spiked with increased testing, according
to the state Department of Health and Human Services.

There were 1,076 new cases of COVID-19 since Thursday, the DHHS reported. That
came after 15,704 completed tests for the virus, a one-day high, as more
testing sites open across the state.

The state reported that there have been 859 deaths from the coronavirus, with
the DHHS data showing 84 percent of the fatalities have been people ages 65 or
older.

title: Coronavirus cases rising among Hispanics
html:
While the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 continues to increase in the Twin Counties, the concern over the number of confirmed cases among Hispanics increases at an even greater rate.

On Friday, Edgecombe County reported 190 cases with nine deaths and 163 people recovered, while Nash County reported 198 total cases with four deaths and 125 people recovered.

During a Friday morning Nash County team management meeting, Health Director Bill Hill reported that his agency was seeing an increased number of positives as testing has increased.

"We expected to see that with the increased testing," he said, "but we are seeing more and more Hispanics (testing positive) and that is a concern."

Hill said that of six new cases heading into Friday, four people were Hispanics. Over the Memorial Day weekend, six members of one Hispanic family, including a 6-year-old, tested positive.

Hill said that in the six latest cases, there was a husband and wife in their 50s, as well as people in their 30s and 40s.

Edgecombe County provides no demographic information, claiming immunity under HIPPA guidelines and citing a belief that by identifying a person testing positive by gender or race, it could lead to their being identified.

Edgecombe County health department officials have declined to reply to at least two e-mails regarding what County Manager Eric Evans told county commissioners was an increasing number of cases among Hispanics.

The next week, when commissioners met in joint session with the Edgecombe County Public Schools board, Evans backed off that statement and said only that, "The demographics are changing daily."

While Edgecombe provides no updates, Nash has visited farm labor camps and met with farmers in an effort to stem the growth of cases among Hispanics as the migrant work force grows.

Even with that, Nash County Manager Zee Lamb said, "There does seems to be a spike in the cases among Hispanics … disproportionately that demographic is growing beyond their population."

Statewide, cases showed a slight decline on Friday in North Carolina, but the number of positive case reports has spiked with increased testing, according to the state Department of Health and Human Services.

There were 1,076 new cases of COVID-19 since Thursday, the DHHS reported. That came after 15,704 completed tests for the virus, a one-day high, as more testing sites open across the state.

The state reported that there have been 859 deaths from the coronavirus, with the DHHS data showing 84 percent of the fatalities have been people ages 65 or older.
